questions.text: A 5-year-old child is referred to a mental health practitioner for evaluation. The practitioner wants to gain insight into the conscious and unconscious preoccupations of the child. To accomplish this objective, the practitioner is most likely to make use of
questions.solution:
Examiner wants to know the test for unconscious activity of a child’s mind. Projective personality tests are used to check the unconscious or latent aspect of personality. Among the given options projective drawing test is a projective personality test.

Option a: The Luria-Nebraska Neuropsychological Battery, also known as LNNB or Luria-Nebraska Battery, is a standardized test battery used in the screening and evaluation of neuropsychologically impaired individuals.

Option b: Minnesota Multiphasic personality inventory is an objective personality test.

Option d: Wechsler scale for children is used to assess intelligence.

Projective personality tests:

Projective tests are intended to uncover feelings, desires, and conflicts that are hidden from conscious awareness.

Stimulus: Ambiguous stimuli are those which do not have a perfect yes or no answer. Examples of this type of stimulus are ink blot, image etc. There are unlimited number of ways in which the patient can interpret the ink blot or any other stimulus. The patient’s responses to these stimuli will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality.

For example, if the stimulus used is paper with an image of 2 persons, interpretation of that image will reflect his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Types:

Test Stimuli
Rorschach test  10 different cards that depict an ambiguous inkblot. Patient is shown one card at a time and asked to describe what they see in the image
Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)  Patient is asked to look at a series of ambiguous scenes and then to tell a story describing the scene
Figure drawing / projective drawing/ Draw a person test  Patient will draw a person and the image created is then assessed by the examiner
Make-a-Picture story Similar to TAT; however, stimuli can be manipulated by the patient
Sentence completion test  Series of sentences with blanks in between to be filled up by the patient
Holtzman Inkblot Technique (HIT) Similar to Rorschach test

Note: Most of these projective drawing tests can be used for children of 4 years of age and above. The drawings need not be perfect. They're to be interpreted as a projection of the child's unconscious mind.

questions.text: Mesolimbic tract is theorized in genesis of Schizophrenia. Which neurotransmitter is found in increased quantities in this tract?
questions.solution:
Mesocortical and Mesolimbic tracts are dopaminergic pathways in brain.

Mesocortical pathway is associated with negative symptoms of schizophrenia and Mesolimbic pathway is associated with positive symptoms of schizophrenia.

Dopaminergic pathways: They are 4 in number

Pathway Anatomy Function
Tuberoinfundibular system Cell bodies in the hypothalamus tothe pituitary stalk Inhibitory control over prolactin secretion.
Nigrostriatal system Cell bodies in the substantia nigra and projects to the basal ganglia Regulating involuntary motor activity
Mesolimbic pathway Ventral tegmentum -  project diffusely to the nucleus accumbens, amygdala, hippocampus,medial dorsal nucleus of the thalamus, and cingulate gyrus. Modulates emotional expression, learning and reinforcement, and hedonic capacity
Mesocortical pathway Ventral tegmentum to orbitofrontal and the prefrontal cortical regions Regulate motivation, concentration, and initiation of goal-directed and complex executive cognitive tasks.

questions.text: Maximum score in MMSE (Mini Mental Status Examination) is:
questions.solution:
Maximum score in MMSE (Mini Mental Status Examination) is 30 and minimum score is 0.

Score less than 24 is considered “impaired”.

MMSE (Mini Mental Status Examination):

Divised by Folstein

Components:

  • Orientation
  • Registration
  • Attention and calculation
  • Recall
  • Language

Advantages:

  • Ease of administration and scoring
  • Less time consuming
  • Can be reliably administered and scored by trained clinic staff
  • Can be tolerated even by very low functioning patients.

Disadvantages:

  • Influenced by education level of patient i.e. highly educated patients with mild Alzheimer disease may perform very well on the MMSE, whereas healthy individuals with low education may earn scores in the “impaired” range.
  • May not identify mild cognitive defects or deficits associated with noncortical dementias.

questions.text: Which is the least preferred benzodiazepine in elderly with liver dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Diazepam is the least preferred benzodiazepine in elderly patient with hepatic dysfunction.

Long-acting benzodiazepines, including chlordiazepoxide and diazepam are metabolized in liver to produce active metabolites. This is responsible for long duration of action. A disadvantage of the long-acting drugs is that they and their active metabolites may accumulate, especially in patients with compromised liver function.

Short acting benzodiazepines like triazolam, temazolam, oxazepam, lorazepam and estazolam (Mnemonic STOLE).

These are rapidly converted to inactive water-soluble metabolites that will not accumulate, and for this reason the short-acting drugs are especially useful in alcoholic patients or elderly patients with liver disease.

questions.text: Which is not true about Hallucination?

choices.text: It is as vivid as normal stimulus
It occur in inner subjective space
It is independent of will of observer
It occurs in absence of perceptual stimuli

questions.solution:
Hallucinations occur in outer objective space, not in inner subjective space i.e. it is perceived to be originating from outer world like someone calling their name etc.

Option a: Hallucinations are as vivid as normal stimulus i.e. patient is not able to differentiate between normal stimulus and hallucination. In case of auditory hallucination they cannot differentiate between voice of normal people and voice causing hallucination.

Option c: It is independent of will of observer i.e. patient cannot manipulate characteristic of hallucination.

Option d: Hallucinations are perceptions that occur in the absence of corresponding sensory stimuli.

questions.text: Bruxism is seen in

choices.text: Stage III and Stage IV of NREM sleep

questions.solution:
Bruxism is maximum in stage II NREM sleep.

  • Sleep-Related Bruxism is diagnosed when an individual grinds or clenches their teeth during sleep.
  • It is the third most frequent sleep disorder after insomnia and snoring.
  • Most episodes of bruxism occur during sleep stages 1 & 2 (approximately 30% & 56% respectively), whilst episodes during stages 3, 4 & Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep are much less likely (approximately 6%, 1% & 7% respectively). Episodes that occur during REM sleep are more frequently associated with facial and dental pain.

questions.text: An IQ of 45 comes under _________
questions.solution:
IQ of 45 comes under moderate MR.

DSM IV (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders) criteria for mental retardation was based on IQ scores:

  • Intelligent quotient (IQ) = Mental age/Chronological age × 100
  • Normal IQ – 90 – 110
  • Mental subnormality – 70 - 90
Type of mental retardation IQ score
Mild 50 – 69
Moderate 35 – 49
Severe 20 – 34
Profound <20

Changes in DSM 5:

  • Word “Mental retardation” has been replaced by “Intellectual disability”.
  • Intellectual Disability (Intellectual Developmental Disorder) is a disorder with onset during the developmental period that includes both intellectual and adaptive functioning deficits in conceptual, social, and practical domains.
  • Severity levels are now classified by adaptive rather than intellectual function or IQ scores.
Criteria DSM-IV-TR/Ed.gov.nl.ca DSM-5
Name (Mental Retardation) COGNITIVE DISORDER Intellectual Disabilities
A: Intellectual function

Significantly subaverge intellectual functioning

IQ≤ 70

 Deficits (reasoning, problem-solving, planning, abstract thinking, etc) confirmed by clinical assessment and individual standardized testing (IQ: 70±5) - intellectual profile
B: Adaptive function Deficits in ≥ 2 areas Deficits in adaptive function result in failure to meet socio-cultural standards (e.g., lack of judgment) and related to intellectual impairments
C: Age at onset Before age 18 During the developmental period
Severity Based on IQ Based on the adaptive function

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic was brought to casualty with a history of agitation and hallucinations since the previous day. He had his last drink three days ago. On examination, the patient has generalized tremulousness and tachycardia, and the liver markers are deranged. Which of the following drugs can be safely used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic with agitation and hallucinatory behaviours along with tremors is suggestive of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Lorazepam is the drug that this patient can use as it can be safely used for liver dysfunction.

Benzodiazepines are the mainstay of treatment of alcohol withdrawal syndrome.

Alcohol withdrawal symptoms include autonomic hyperactivity such as increased pulse rate, blood pressure, and body temperature, restlessness, disturbed sleep, anxiety, nausea, tremors and severe withdrawal involving auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations, delirium, seizures, and coma.

These are commonly treated with benzodiazepines such as oxazepam, diazepam, chlordiazepoxide, and lorazepam. Diazepam (Option C) and chlordiazepoxide(Option B) require less frequent dosing but are not useful in the elderly or patients with hepatic dysfunction. Due to its short half-life and metabolism through glucuronidation only, lorazepam is best for the treatment of alcohol withdrawal in older adults. Lorazepam and oxazepam can also be used in patients with hepatic dysfunction.

Other options:

Option D:  Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor used in major depressive disorder. It increases appetite and causes significant weight gain.

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Manifestation
Symptoms/signs
Onset since last drink (hours)
Tremulousness
Continuous tremor of > 8 Hz (or) Bursts of tremor activity < 8 Hz
6–8
Alcoholic hallucinosis/
Psychotic and perceptual symptoms
Visual, auditory or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs. 
8-12
Seizures (rum fits)
Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic
12–24
Delirium tremens
Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, impaired orientation
< 72

questions.text: A 20 years old female who had outstanding scholastic performance till about high school was noticed to become odd and eccentric in behavior compared to peers, would ruminate, had extremely brief psychotic episodes for 1 week. She had beliefs about supernatural powers and life after death. Her self-care has been adequate along with normal sleep and appetite. She might be suffering from
questions.solution:
Odd and eccentric behavior, magical thinking (supernatural powers) suggest Schizotypal personality disorder.

Option b: Episodes are extremely brief. Schizophrenia requires symptoms to be present for at least 1 month.

Option c and d: Outstanding scholastic performance and onset of symptoms only at 20 years rules out borderline intelligence and autism.

Cluster A personality disorder/ odd or eccentric group - core traits of being interpersonally distant and emotionally constricted.

It includes

  • Paranoid personalities are quick to feel slighted and jealous, carry grudges, and distrustful and suspicious i.e. expect to be exploited and harmed by others.
  • Schizoid personalities prefer to be alone, detached, unemotional - lack friendships or close relationships with others and are indifferent to praise or criticism by others.
  • Schizotypal personalities display eccentric and odd beliefs, engage in odd and eccentric gestures and practices, and exhibit odd speech.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: A 20 years old female presents with a recent break up in a relationship, followed by consumption of 30 tablets of Diazepam. She on questioning reports of past history of multiple relationship issues, has come out of home after a trivial quarrel and multiple Deliberate Self Harm attempts in the past. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
History of unstable relationship and episodes of self harm are suggestive of borderline personality disorder.

Borderline personality disorder is included under cluster B personality disorder.

Cluster B personality disorder / dramatic, emotional, and erratic group:

Patients with these personality disorders characteristically have chaotic lives, emotions, and relationships.

  • Borderline personalities are impulsive, unpredictable, angry, temperamental, unstable in relationships, compulsively interpersonal, and self-damaging with regard to sex, money, and substance use.
  • Histrionic personalities are attention seeking, exhibitionistic, seductive, self-indulgent, exhibit exaggerated expressions of emotions, and overconcerned with physical appearance.
  • Narcissistic personalities tend to be hypersensitive to criticism, exploitative of others, egocentric with an inflated sense of self-importance, feel entitled to special treatment, and demand constant attention.
  • Antisocial personalities are truant, lie, steal, start fights, break rules, are unable to sustain work or school and shirk everyday responsibilities.

questions.text: Five months after her husband’s death, the lady was noticed to be talking to self, crying, reporting of hearing voices of her husband asking her to join him. She reports of feeling extremely sad, disinterested and has been having poor sleep. The probable diagnosis could be _________
questions.solution:
Symptoms are suggestive of Grief reaction

Option A: 2-12 months: normal grief. Symptoms are mild to moderate depression and preoccupation with thoughts of dead ones.

In this, hearing the dead or seeing them is not considered a hallucination. Insistent thoughts and memories of the lost person, sometimes including hallucinations can be normally seen in acute grief reaction.treatment is SSRI/TCA + supportive psychotherapy

Option B: 5 of 9 symptoms: sleep disturbances, appetite change, low energy, psychomotor changes, low mood, anhedonia, guilt, concentration difficulty, suicidal ideation for ≥ 2 weeks.

Option C: Sadness, disinterest better correlates with grief than schizophrenia.

Option D: 5 months duration is inadequate to be classified as Dysthymia or persistent depressive disorder. Dysthymia is defined as depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years.

questions.text: All of the following are complications seen in patients with Anorexia Nervosa, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Hypokalaemic alkalosis, hyperprolactinemia, hypothyroidism can be complications of seen in anorexia nervosa.

Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by 3 core features

  • Significantly low body weight based on age and height
  • Intense fear of gaining weight or becoming fat or persistent behaviors that interfere with achieving adequate weight.
  • Disturbances in the experience of body shape or weight.

It is of 2 types:

  • Restricting type: During the last 3 months, the individual has not engaged in recurrent episodes of binge eating or purging behavior (i.e., self-induced vomiting or the misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or enemas). This subtype describes presentations in which weight loss is accomplished primarily through dieting, fasting, and/or excessive exercise.
  • Binge eating/purging type: During the last 3 months, the individual has engaged in recurrent episodes of binge eating or purging behavior (i.e., self-induced vomiting or the misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or enemas).

Common Medical and Physical Complications Associated with anorexia nervosa:

General:

  • Low weight
  • Loss of body fat
  • Muscle Atrophy
  • Hypothermia

Skin

  • Lanugo (fine hair growth on body)
  • Hair loss or thinning
  • Carotenemia (Yellowing of skin)

Cardiovascular

  • Arrhythmias
  • Bradycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Orthostasis
  • Prolonged QTc
  • Peripheral edema

Gastrointestinal

  • Delayed gastric emptying
  • Constipation

Electrolyte/metabolic

  • Hypokalemia (low potassium)
  • Hyponatremia (low sodium)
  • Hypochloremia (low chloride)
  • Alkalosis
  • Hypercholesterolemia (high cholesterol)
  • Hypoglycemia (low blood sugar)
  • Elevated liver Enzymes

Endocrine

  • Low luteinizing hormone
  • Low follicle stimulating hormone
  • Low estrogen or testosterone
  • Low thyroxine
  • Hyperprolactinemia
  • Elevated cortisol
  • Amenorrhea
  • Decreased bone mineral density (can lead to osteopenia or osteoporosis)

Haematological

  • Leukopenia
  • Anemia

questions.text: Basanti, a 27-year-old female, thinks her nose is ugly; her idea is fixed and not shared by anyone else. Whenever she goes out of home, she hides her face with a cloth. She visits a surgeon. Next step would be
questions.solution:
• Patient is suffering from body dysmorphic disorder which is a disorder in which patients distortedly perceive and intensely dislike the shape of a particular body part.
  • As such, these symptoms are misnamed because there is no true phobic component such as fear or avoidant behavior.
  • In this case the patient thinks that her nose is ugly even when it is not agreed upon by others. She is suffering from body dysmorphic disorder.
  • Hence it is necessary to refer the patient to psychiatrist.
  • Body dysmorphic disorder also called dysmorphophobia is included on the obsessive compulsive spectrum in DSM-5.

questions.text: Characteristic finding of subcortical degeneration is
questions.solution:
The Subcortical dementia is the disorders in which the predominant pathological lesions occur in subcortical structures such as basal ganglia. It is charactised by

  • Cognitive impairment - Memory, visuospatial skills, information processing speed, attention, explicit recall, spatial planning, perseveration, verbal fluency, and poverty of thought are affected.
  • Movement disorders characterized primarily by subcortical neuropathology.

Aphasia, agnosia, apraxia, and abnormal recognition memory and higher language functions are all features of cortical dementia like Alzheimer’s disease.

Mnemonic:

  • M symptoms i.e. motor movement problems and memory impairment in case of subcortical dementia.
  • A symptoms i.e. apraxia, agnosia, aphasia, astereognosis, acalculia etc are seen in case of cortical dementia.

questions.text: Splitting is a characteristic feature in
questions.solution:
Splitting is a defense mechanism in which external objects are divided into “all good” and “all bad,” accompanied by the abrupt shifting of an object from one extreme category to the other.

For example patients with borderline personality disorder don’t see people as good person with few bad qualities. They consider them to be either completely good or completely bad.

It is also known as “All or none thinking”, “Black and white thinking” or “Dichotomous thinking”.

It is one of the 9 criteria for diagnosis of Borderline personality disorder under DSM 5.

  • Intense and stormy relationships that involve splitting
  • Feeling persistently empty or bored
  • A warped view of yourself that affects your emotions, values, moods, and relationships
  • Impulsive behavior, such as abusing substances or driving recklessly
  • Anger issues, such as violent outbursts followed by extreme guilt and remorse
  • Extreme attempts to avoid abandonment or extreme feelings of abandonment
  • Suicidal thoughts and/or self-harming behaviors
  • Extreme depression, anxiety, or irritability that can persist for hours and days
  • Feeling dissociated from yourself, including paranoia and amnesia

questions.text: Clinical problems in Huntington’s chorea are secondary to the damage of:
questions.solution:
Clinical problems in Huntington’s chorea are secondary to damage of GABAergic neurons in striatum.

Huntington disease is an autosomal dominant disorder involving an excess of trinucleotide repeats (CAG repeats) in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4. Pathophysiology:

Atrophy of the caudate nuclei, almost a pathognomonic macroscopic finding, correlates roughly with the severity of dementia.

Phenomenon of anticipation (younger age of onset in subsequent generations of a family) occurs in Huntington’s disease.

Mnemonic:

Remember letter “D” which is the 4th alphabet:

  • 4th decade
  • 4th chromosome
  • Autosomal Dominant
  • CauDate and putamen affected
  • Dementia

Alphabet “C” before “D” – Chorea and CAG repeats

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Resistant Depression?

choices.text: Not associated with Axis II issues and Chemical dependence
Thyroxine can be used for augmentation
10 – 20% of people who present with clinical depression, might progress into Resistant Depression

questions.solution:
Resistant depression is associated with axis II issues which includes personality disorder.

The DSM-IV-TR used multiaxial system:

Axis-I: clinical disorders and other conditions that could be a focus of clinical disorders.

Axis-II: personality disorders and mental retardation.

Axis-III: general medical conditions.

Axis-IV: psychosocial and environmental problems.

Axis-V: global assessment of functioning (GAF) within the last six months.

At present DSM V uses single axial system for diagnosis.

Option b:

Augmentation therapy for resistant depression:

  • Addition of another antidepressant
  • Antipsychotic
  • Thyroxine
  • Lithium
  • ECT
  • Transcranial magnetic stimulation

Option c: 10 – 20% of people who present with clinical depression, might progress into Resistant Depression

Option d: Non specific white matter changes maybe seen in resistant depression.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mature defense mechanism?
questions.solution:
Repression is a neurotic/immature defense mechanism.

Mature defense mechanisms: These mechanisms are healthy and adaptive throughout the life cycle. They are socially adaptive and useful in the integration of personal needs and motives, social demands, and interpersonal relations. They can underlie seemingly admirable and virtuous patterns of behavior.

It includes:

  • Anticipation
  • Humor
  • Altruism
  • Ascetism
  • Suppression
  • Sublimation

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: All of the following increases the likelihood of a True Seizure, EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Prolactin levels rise (>1000 IU/L), 10 to 20 min postictally in case of true seizures.

 

Difference between epileptic and Nonepileptic seizures:

Epileptic seizures Non epileptic seizures
Not inducible Inducible by suggesion and triggers like stress.
Aura > 10 seconds No aura, or aura <5 seconds
Movements are stereotyped, rhythmic, synchronic and flexor. Movements are less sterotyped, asynchronous, flexor and extensor out of phase, waxing and waning, and of a bizarre character.

questions.text: Seizures occurring during every menstrual cycle is called
questions.solution:
Catamenial epilepsy is epilepsy occuring during menstrual cycle.

Cause: It may be due to

  • Effects of estrogen and progesterone on neuronal excitability
  • Changes in antiepileptic drug levels due to altered protein binding or metabolism.

Treatment:

  • Some patients may benefit from increases in antiepileptic drug dosages during menses.
  • Natural progestins or intramuscular medroxyprogesterone may be of benefit to a subset of women.

questions.text: Physical dependence is seen in
questions.solution:
Cocaine, alcohol and amphetamines can produce physical dependence.

Physical dependence indicates an altered physiological state due to repeated administrations of a drug, the cessation of which results in the appearance of a withdrawal or abstinence syndrome characteristic for the particular drug which is called discontinuation syndrome.

Psychological dependence or addiction refers to compulsive, relapsing drug use despite negative consequences.

questions.text: Schizophrenia is not associated with
questions.solution:
Schizophrenia has good prognosis.

  • Emil Kraepelin described two major groups of primary psychotic disorders: The manic depressive psychosis and dementia praecox.
  • Long-term prognosis and course of illness were the principle features to define these two distinct categories
  • Dementia praecox (Called schizophrenia at present) was deemed as deteriorating and irreversible with bad prognosis
  • Manic depressive psychosis (Now called bipolar/mood disorder) was thought as having good prognosis
  • Now a days with advent of antipsychotics and other forms of treatment, both conditions have better prognosis. Earlier concept that schizophrenia corresponds to poor prognosis doesn’t hold good at present

The two-syndrome concept as formulated by T. J. Crow: He classified schizophrenia into 2 types:

Feature Type I Type II
Presentation Acute Chronic
Symptoms Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Response to neuroleptics Good response Poor response
CT/MRI Normal Abnormal like enlarged ventricles, small hippocampus and temporal lobe

Positive symptoms of schizophrenia:

  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions
  • Bizarre behavior
  • Positive formal thought disorder

Negative symptoms of schizophrenia:

  • Affective flattening/Blunting - Inability to understand or recognize displays of emotion from others and an inability to express emotion. It is an important predictor of functional impairment in schizophrenia.
  • Alogia - Decrease in verbal communication, or “poverty of speech,”
  • Avolition/apathy - Loss of will or drive
  • Anhedonia - Loss of the ability to find or derive pleasure from activities or relationships and may be the most persistent of the negative symptoms
  • Attention impairment

Option a: MRI changes in schizophrenia are

  • Reductions in hippocampal or amygdala-hippocampal volumes - associated with verbal and declarative memory deficits, similar to findings in schizophrenia.
  • Increased third ventricle volume

Option b: Excess resting slow wave activity in EEG in schizophrenia.

Option c: Schizophrenia is often associated with severe loss of functioning and shortened life expectancy. Suicides and accidents are well-known causes of the excess mortality, but patients with schizophrenia have also been reported to be three times as likely to experience sudden unexpected death as individuals from the general population.

questions.text: What is anaclitic depression?

choices.text: Depression in infants when separated from primary caregiver
Depression seen in autism spectrum disorder

questions.solution: Anaclitic depression, also known as hospitalism, is a type of depression in infants where sudden separation from their primary caregivers leads to depression, withdrawal, nonresponsiveness, and loss of milestones in the infants. However, they recover when their mothers return or when surrogate mothering is available.

questions.text: A 60-year-old is brought to the psychiatrist with a 10-year history that he suspects his neighbors sneeze whenever he passes and they plan against him. He feels that his wife is replaced by a double, he called police for help, and he is alert, well groomed, and an occasional alcoholic. He is most probably suffering from:
questions.solution:
Patient is presenting with

  • Persecutory delusion – Neighbors planning against him
  • Delusion of misidentification – Wife is replaced by a double i.e. Capgras syndrome

Paranoid schizophrenia is a type of schizophrenia characterized by the presence of persecutory delusions, referential delusions, grandiose delusions and delusion of misidentification, often accompanied by hallucinations.

Option a: Paranoid personality is a Cluster A personality disorder with features like - quick to feel slighted and jealous, carry grudges, and distrustful and suspicious i.e. expect to be exploited and harmed by others. This doesn’t explain Capgras syndrome.

Option c: Patient is occasional alcoholic.

Option d: Conversion disorder doesn’t explain given symptoms.

questions.text: A doctor, who smokes, asserts that smoking is beneficial because it inhibits the development of obesity is using which of the following "defense" mechanisms?
questions.solution:
• Defense mechanism used here is rationalization.
  • Rationalization - Ernest Jones’s term for an unconscious defense mechanism in which irrational or unacceptable behavior, motives, or feelings are logically justified or made consciously tolerable by plausible means.
  • Smoking is harmful to health but doctor is justifying it by giving logical reason like it avoids development of obesity.

Option b: Intellectualization - Unconscious defense mechanism in which reasoning or logic is used in an attempt to avoid confrontation with an objectionable impulse and thus defend against anxiety. Also called brooding compulsion; thinking compulsion.

Note:

  • Intellectualization and rationalization are often used interchangeably, which is incorrect.
  • Rationalization involves rationalizing one's thoughts to justify the action, whereas intellectualization involves acknowledging only the facts and ignoring the emotions.
  • Intellectualization involves blocking out and/or ignoring the emotional side of any problem and, instead, viewing the problem in a completely rational and intellectual manner by comprehending only the facts associated with it.
  • For example: On learning that he has been diagnosed with leukemia, ram does not go into depression and feelings of anxiety and sadness, instead he sits down to research about the disease and what it involves, he looks up self-help groups and tries to face the situation in this manner.

Option c: Reaction formation Unconscious defense mechanism in which a person develops a socialized attitude or interest that is the direct antithesis of some infantile wish or impulse that is harbored either consciously or unconsciously. For example: Ram has a lot of unconscious hostility toward his father but he acts very affectionate toward him and tells other people that he and his father have a wonderful relationship.  

Option a: Dissociation - Unconscious defense mechanism involving the segregation of any group of mental or behavioral processes from the rest of the person’s psychic activity; may entail the separation of an idea from its accompanying emotional tone, as seen in dissociative and conversion disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are known to cause behavioural problems in children?
questions.solution:
Barbiturates can cause paradoxical excitement especially among children, geriatric and debilitated patients and occurs most frequently with phenobarbital and N-methylbarbiturates.

Option b: Benzodiazepines may cause disinhibition or dyscontrol bizarre uninhibited behavior like euphoria, restlessness, hallucinations, sleep-walking, sleep-talking, other complex behaviors, and hypomanic behavior together with hostility and rage.

Option d: Atomoxetine is a selective Norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used in the treatment of ADHD.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for obsessive-compulsive disorder?
questions.solution:
SSRIs (Fluoxetine among given options) are the drug of choice for obsessive compulsive disorder.

Remember: Clomipramine, a relatively serotonergic tricyclic antidepressant is most effective in case of OCD.

In head-to-head comparisons of clomipramine and SSRIs, there is equal efficacy, but SSRIs are better tolerated.

questions.text: The orexins belong to what class of neurochemical?
questions.solution:
Orexins (Previously known as hypocretins) are neuropeptides synthesized by hypothalamic neurons and involved in regulation of food intake and energy expenditure and also in sleep regulation.

Orexinergic neurons project from the hypothalamus to a number of monoaminergic centers including the locus coeruleus, raphe nuclei, and ventral tegmentum.

Functions:

  • Regulation of sleep: 
    • Hypothalamus – key regulating centre
    • GABAergic neurons of the ventrolateral preoptic area (VLPO) - Sleep-promoting
    • Orexinergic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus - Wakefulness-promoting
  • Regulation of food intake and energy expenditure. Orexin production can increase food craving

Narcolepsy:

It is sleep disorder characterised by

  • Excessive daytime somnolence/Sleep attacks
  • Cataplexy  - a sudden loss of muscle tone, often triggered by strong emotional reactions
  • Hypnagogic hallucinations  - Hallucinations which occur while going to sleep
  • Sleep paralysis

Other features of narcolepsy:

  • Associated with obesity
  • Leucocytosis in the absence of infection
  • Impotence
  • HLA associations: HLA DR15, HLA DQ6, DQB1*602
  • Both sleep latency and REM latency is reduced. Normal sleep latency is 20-40 min; Normal REM latency is 90 min.
  • Approximately 90 percent of patients, orexin levels in the CSF are low or nonexistent.

questions.text: Type II Schizophrenia is characterized by all except?
questions.solution:
Disorganised behavior is a feature of hebephrenia.

Hebephrenia - Complex of symptoms, considered a form of schizophrenia, characterized by wild or silly behavior or mannerisms, inappropriate affect, frequent Hypochondriacal complaints, and delusions and hallucinations that are transient and unsystematized.

Hebephrenia is the most heritable of the traditional subtypes of schizophrenia.

The two-syndrome concept as formulated by T. J. Crow: He classified schizophrenia into 2 types:

Feature Type I Type II
Presentation Acute Chronic
Symptoms Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Response to neuroleptics Good response Poor response
CT/MRI Normal Abnormal like enlarged ventricles, small hippocampus and temporal lobe

Positive symptoms of schizophrenia:

  • Hallucinations
  • Delusion
  • Bizarre behavior
  • Positive formal thought disorder

Negative symptoms of schizophrenia:

  • Affective flattening/Blunting - Inability to understand or recognize displays of emotion from others and an inability to express emotion. It is an important predictor of functional impairment in schizophrenia.
  • Alogia - Decrease in verbal communication, or “poverty of speech,”
  • Avolition/apathy - Loss of will or drive
  • Anhedonia - Loss of the ability to find or derive pleasure from activities or relationships and may be the most persistent of the negative symptoms.
  • Attention impairment

questions.text: The parents of a three-year-old boy are seeking a therapist for their son. He is a three-year-old with normal developmental milestones but with poor speech abilities, inability to socialize with peers, restricted and repetitive behaviour with impaired non-verbal communication. Which of the following conditions is the boy most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a 3-year-old boy having poor speech abilities and inability to socialize but has normal developmental milestones is most likely suffering from autism.

Autism spectrum disorder refers to a phenotypically heterogeneous group of neurodevelopmental syndromes, characterized by a wide range of impairments in social communication along with restricted and repetitive behaviors. It is four times more common in boys than in girls.

Prior to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Dis­orders (DSM-5), autism spectrum disorder was conceptualized as five different disorders, that included autistic disorder, Asperger's disorder, childhood disintegrative disorder, Rett syndrome, and pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified.

The DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder are:
  • Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction that includes a failure to communicate, lack of empathy, abnormalities in eye contact, stereotyped or absent speech, and either hyper or hypo-arousal to the environment
  • Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities, as manifested by any two of the following: (i) Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects or speech (ii) insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns of verbal/nonverbal behavior (iii) highly restricted and fixated interests (iv) hyper or hypoactivity to sensory input
  • Symptoms are present in the early developmental period, but may not fully manifest until later in life.
  • Symptoms cause impairment in social, occupational, and other important areas of functioning.
  • The disturbances cannot be explained by any intellectual disability.

It can be diagnosed by using the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule-Generic (ADOS-G).

Other options:

Option A: Schizophrenia is characterized by hallucinations or delusions, and childhood-onset schizophrenia has a lower incidence of seizures, intellectual disability, and poor social skills. It is rare in children younger than 5 years. 

Option C: Language Disorder is equally common in boys and girls. The child actively uses non-verbal communication like gestures and any impaired social communication, restricted and repetitive behavior is absent.

Option D: ADHD (Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) is characterized by a poor attention span with distractibility, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.

questions.text: What diagnosis is given when physical symptoms are deliberately faked or exaggerated for a conscious reason?
questions.solution:
Faking symptoms for a conscious reason is malingering.

Malingering is defined as feigning disease in order to achieve a specific goal, for example, to avoid an unpleasant responsibility.

Option b: Hypochondriasis/Somatic symptom disorder/Somatization disorder/Somatoform disorder/Briquet syndrome is characterized by

  • Preoccupation with the false belief of having a serious disease
  • Multiple, recurrent physical complaints with no apparent physical cause
  • Symptoms have no demonstrable organic findings, are often misinterpreted by the patient, and are apparently linked to psychological factors.

Option c: Factitious disorder/Munchausen syndrome is a mental disorder characterized by the voluntary production of false or unreal physical or psychological symptoms; unlike malingering, there is no apparent goal or obvious benefit.

Pseudologia fantastica i.e. excess, dramatic lying is a feature.

Question says conscious reason which is absent is factitious disorder.

Option d: Conversion disorder now termed as functional neurological symptom disorder is a mental disorder in which the patient experiences an involuntary limitation or alteration of physical function that is an expression of a psychological conflict or need, not of a physical disorder.

questions.text: True about Venlafaxine is

choices.text: It acts on Serotonin pathways only
It is not useful in cases of OCD
Hypertension is a common problem noticed with regular use
Not available in extended release form

questions.solution:
Higher-dose venlafaxine therapy is associated with an increased risk of sustained elevations of blood pressure. Hence monitoring of BP is recommended.

Option a: Venlafaxine is a serotonin Norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

Option b: Venlafaxine can be used in OCD. It is approved for treatment of depression, anxiety and panic disorders.

Option d: It is available in extended release form and this form reduces incidence of nausea which is the most common side effect of Venlafaxine.

Other SNRIs:

  • Duloxetine - Approved for depression, anxiety, peripheral neuropathy, and fibromyalgia
  • Desvenlafaxine - Approved for depression
  • Milnacipran - Approved for fibromyalgia

questions.text: Miss Ramya has a fear of contamination, which causes her to wash her hands hundreds of times a day, and causes panic attacks when she must change a diaper in her job as a nanny. She would most likely be diagnosed with:
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Obsessive compulsive disorder - fear of contamination is the obsession and frequent hand washing is the compulsion.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a neurotic disorder characterized by the persistent recurrence of obsessions and compulsions.

Obsessions are intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses that often lead to a marked increase in anxiety or distress.

These thoughts are egodystonic i.e. ego is not recognizing thoughts as rational.

Compulsions are repeated behaviors or mental acts that are done in response to obsessions, or in a rigid rule-bound way.

questions.text: A male patient is being treated for chronic schizophrenia with haloperidol. One week after the initiation of therapy, he complains of restlessness, inability to sit in one place, and fidgetiness. Which of the following is the most effective treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Increase in the dose of haloperidol

questions.solution:
The clinical features point to a diagnosis of medication-induced acute akathisia for which the most effective treatment is the addition of a beta-blocker.

Akathisia is the subjective feelings and/or objective signs of restlessness. These include rocking motions while sitting, jitteriness, pacing, and inability to relax. Medication-induced akathisia develops within a few weeks of starting or raising the dose of certain medications. Antipsychotics, antidepressants, and sympathomimetics have been implicated in causing the condition. It can also be seen after reducing a medication used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms.

Dose-reduction, pharmacotherapy, and change of neuroleptic are the primary modalities used in the treatment. Beta-blockers like propranolol are considered the most effective agents. Benzodiazepines like lorazepam and anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl and benztropine are used next.

It is more commonly seen in middle-aged women. It can be associated with a poor treatment outcome.

questions.text: Which of the following topics is principally focused on in cognitive therapy
questions.solution:
Cognitive behavioral therapy helps in identifying and changing faulty ideas and beliefs.

Aaron Beck’s cognitive triad of depression – He identified that depression is because of highly negative, distorted, and dysfunctional beliefs and thoughts and proposed cognitive triad of depression.

CBT helps in identifying these thoughts and modifying response to those thoughts.  

Cognitive model states that response (emotional, behavioural and physical) to any situation depends on person’s perception of situation. For example how a normal and depressed person perceives same situation is depicted in below chart

So cognitive behavioural therapy involves

  • Evaluating cognitions i.e. teaching patients to identify the thoughts that lead to distress or dysfunction, to evaluate their thinking.
  • Modifying behaviour - effectively respond to these cognitions

Cognitive behavior therapy triangle:

  • Components (Mnemonic BET) – Behavior, thoughts and emotions.
  • It is bidirectional i.e. components influence each other. For example, thought influences behaviour and behavior influences thoughts.

Levels of thoughts:  

  • Automatic thoughts: These arise in the mind spontaneously, without conscious reflection. 
    • Cognitive distortions are also known as thinking errors, thinking distortions, irrational thoughts, distorted thoughts, and negative automatic thoughts are irrational or extreme thinking patterns that affect one's perception of reality, usually in a negative way and provoke or exacerbate symptoms of depression.
  • Intermediate level includes rules/ core beliefs/ errors:
    • Core beliefs are one’s most central ideas about the self, other people, and the world. 
    • In psychiatric illness patients begin to view themselves, their worlds, and/or other people through a negative lens, interpreting their experience in a highly negative way.  
  • Deep level
    • Schemas - Schemas are responsible for processing, storing, and retrieving different types of information, including perceptions, goals, expectations, memories, fantasies, and prior learning.
    • Modes - complex organization of schemas related to individuals’ self-evaluations, rules, memories, and expectancies.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Vilazodone:
questions.solution:
Vilazodone is a novel dual-acting serotonergic antidepressant that combines the effect of Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor with 5HT1A-receptor partial agonist activity.

It has faster onset of action - Peak concentrations occur at 4 to 5 hours after administration. It has a terminal half-life of about 25 hours and achieves steady state in approximately 3 days

Option a: Vilazodone was not associated with any clinically significant effects on electrocardiograms, arrhythmias, or QTc abnormalities.

Option b: It is an antidepressant. Only FDA-recommended indication for vilazodone is for the treatment of Major Depression in adults.

Option d: It is primarily metabolized by CYP3A4, with minor contributions from CYP2C19 and CYP2D6.

questions.text: Lalla, 22-year-old male has a history of restless, excessive speech, spending lot of money, increased activity, increased sexual desire, and decreased sleep. Most probable diagnosis will be:
questions.solution:
Features are suggestive of mania.

Mania is a mood abnormality characterized by

  • Elation
  • Agitation
  • Hyperactivity
  • Hyperexcitability
  • Accelerated thinking and speaking (flight of ideas)
  • Decreased need for sleep;
  • Overinvolvement in pleasurable behavior

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents at the local clinic complaining of abdominal cramps, sweating, runny nose, vomiting, and muscle aches. Examination shows that his pulse is rapid and pupils are dilated. He states that he "feels just awful" and that he has had these symptoms for about 24 hours. The most likely pharmacologic treatment would be:
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms are suggestive of opioid withdrawal and clonidine is the drug of choice.

Opiate withdrawal symptoms of irritability, anxiety, sweating, sniffling, rhinorrhea, nausea, diarrhea, lacrimation, abdominal pain, headache, muscular pain, and insomnia. During withdrawal, neural activity in the Locus coeruleus (high norepinephrine content) is greatly increased, and this surge is thought to be responsible for many of the symptoms seen during withdrawal.

Clonidine is an α2-adrenergic (presynaptic) agonist. Clonidine activates presynaptic autoreceptors in the locus coeruleus to reduce norepinephrine release and turnover in the cerebral cortex. It thus decreases these symptoms by counteracting catecholamine release and decreasing the sympathetic hyperactivity in opiate withdrawal.

questions.text: All of the following are characteristics of obsessive thoughts except

choices.text: Thoughts are not simply excessive worries about real-life problems
Person attempts to ignore or suppress such thoughts
Thoughts are imposed by an external agency

questions.solution:
Thought insertion – a delusion that thoughts are being implanted in one’s mind by other people or forces is a feature of schizophrenia.

Option a: Excessive worries about real-life problems are seen in generalised anxiety disorder.

Option b: Obsessions are defined as recurrent and persistent thoughts, urges, or images that are experienced, at some point during the disturbance, as intrusive and unwanted, and that in most individuals cause marked anxiety or distress.

Option c: The individual attempts to ignore or suppress such obsessive thoughts, urges, or images, or to neutralize them with some other thought or action (i.e. by performing a compulsion).

questions.text: Buspirone is an
questions.solution:
Buspirone is an Anxiolytic.

It is a partial agonist at 5HT1A receptor and antagonist at D2 receptor.

Buspirone is primarily effective in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder, but not for other anxiety disorders.

Buspirone mimics the antianxiety properties of benzodiazepines but does not interact with GABAA receptors and or display the sedative and anticonvulsant properties of benzodiazpeines.

questions.text: Where in the brain would you find the locus coeruleus?

choices.text: The pontine region of the brainstem

questions.solution:
Locus coeruleus is a nucleus (a collection of neuronal cell bodies) that is located in the pons (a region of the brain stem) and contains the largest population of noradrenergic neurons in a single identified brain region.

  • These neurons project their axons to virtually every region of the brain and together with other nuclei located in the antero-dorsal part of the brainstem, it forms 'ascending reticular activating system', an area critical for arousal and wakefulness.
  • This key neuromodulatory system is currently thought to be critical for numerous functions including response to stress, attention, emotion, motivation, decision making and learning and memory.

questions.text: A 16 yr old boy does not attend school because of the fear of being harmed by schoolmates. He thinks that his classmates laugh at & talk about him. He is even scared of going out to the market. He is most likely suffering from:
questions.solution:
Boy presents with following features:

  • Persecutory delusion – fear of being harmed by schoolmates
  • Referential delusion – classmates laugh at him and talk about him
  • Acting out – delusional belief that others will harm him. He is acting out on delusion i.e. he stopped going out to the market.

All these suggest diagnosis of schizophrenia.

questions.text: Agoraphobia is fear of
questions.solution:
Agoraphobia is defined as morbid fear of places from which the patient feels that he/she cannot escape. Claustrophobia is a type of agoraphobia.

The DSM-5 defines agoraphobia as characterized by fear (imminent) or anxiety (anticipated) in multiple public situations, be they amongst crowds or simply being out alone.

Option b:Acarophobia is fear of Small objects.

Option c: Nosocomephobia is fear of hospitals.

The phobic person may realize that the fear is irrational but is, nonetheless, unable to dispel it.

questions.text: A person when asked what are similarly between a chair and table, he says that both have four legs. This is
questions.solution:
This is an example of concrete thinking.

Concrete thinking is defined as thinking characterized by actual things and events and immediate experience, rather than by abstractions; seen in young children, in those who have lost or never developed the ability to generalize (as in certain organic mental disorder), and in schizophrenic persons.

Option b: Abstract thinking (Also called abstract attitude; categorical attitude) is defined as thinking characterized by the ability to assume a mental set voluntarily, to shift voluntarily from one aspect of a situation to another, to keep in mind simultaneously various aspects of a situation, to grasp the essentials of a whole and to break a whole into its parts, to discern common properties, to plan, to assume make-believe attitudes, and to think or act symbolically. The capacity for abstract thinking is frequently impaired in patients with organic mental disorders and schizophrenia.

In simple terms, concrete thinking is based on facts or what the person sees while abstract thinking is based on ideas and involves some mental process. For example when a proverb is given, concrete thinker takes literal meaning of each word whereas abstract thinker can understand the hidden meaning in proverb; Like a concrete thinker would interpret “People who live in glass houses should not throw stones” to refer literally to breakable panes of glass. An abstract thinker, in contrast, would understand that the figure of speech means that people who have faults of their own should not criticize others.

Option c: Neologism - New word or phrase whose derivation cannot be understood; often seen in schizophrenia.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is restless and hardly ever on his seat and roams around the hall, and whole of the class has difficulty to concentrate. This boy is suffering from:
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) (Hyperkinetic syndrome, hyperactive child syndrome, and minimal brain dysfunction) has 3 cardinal features:

  • Hyperactivity
  • Impulsivity
  • Inattention

For formal diagnosis of ADHD it is necessary for symptoms be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities and be present in two or more settings.

DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for ADHD defines three types of presentations based on two criteria lists of nine symptoms of inattention and nine symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity.

  • ADHD predominantly inattentive presentation - Children with six or more symptoms of inattention and fewer than six symptoms of hyperactivity
  • ADHD predominantly hyperactive/impulsive presentation – Children with six or more symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsivity and fewer than six symptoms of inattention
  • ADHD combined presentation is diagnosed if full criteria from both lists are met.

questions.text: Prophylactic maintenance serum lithium level is
questions.solution:
Concentrations considered to be effective and acceptably safe are between 0.6 and 1.5 mEq/L.

Lower values (0.6-1.0 mEq/L) are considered adequate and are safer for long-term prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristic is an indicator of pathology more than a normal experience?
questions.solution:
Overinclusive thinking occurs in patient with schizophrenia whereas depersonalization, Hypnogogic hallucination and illusion can occur in normal individuals.

Overinclusive thinking - Patient cannot maintain the boundaries of a topic and restrict his/her thoughts to the limits of a topic. It is a seen in patients with schizophrenia.

Option b: Depersonalization - Called depersonalization disorder in DSM-5, a disordered sensation of unreality concerning oneself, parts of oneself, or one’s environment that occurs under extreme stress or fatigue. It is also seen in schizophrenia and schizotypal disorder.

Option c: Hypnagogic hallucination - Hallucination occurring while falling asleep, not ordinarily considered pathological.

Option d: Illusion is defined as perceptual misinterpretation of a real external stimulus. It can occur in normal individuals also.

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is commonly due to
questions.solution:
Premature ejaculation is now termed early ejaculation. Anxiety is the most common cause of early ejaculation.

The diagnosis is made when a man regularly ejaculates before or within approximately 1 minute after penetration (Only vaginal penetration is considered in DSM V).

questions.text: A hospital inpatient, in an intensive care unit, for the past two days was noticed to be agitated and showing hallucinatory behavior. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the clinical scenario is best explained by encephalopathy. Acute onset of agitation and hallucinations can occur in delirium caused by encephalopathy. 

Other options:

Absence of a history of seizure  in the question rules out postictal confusion.

White coat syndrome is a condition where a patient’s blood pressure is higher when taken in a medical setting than it is in other settings, such as at home probably because of associated anxiety and stress at a clinical setting

Ganser syndrome also known as “Prison psychosis” or “Syndrome of approximate answers” is a type of conversion/dissociative disorder. It is characterized by giving of approximate answers (Vorbeireden) to questions. The answers often just miss the mark but bear an obvious relation to the question, indicating that it has been understood.

questions.text: Percentage of monozygotic twins with schizophrenia:
questions.solution:
Risk of development of schizophrenia in monozygotic twins is 48%.

Risk of development of schizophrenia:

  • General population – 1%
  • One parent affected – 8%
  • Both parents affected – 40%
  • Monozygotic twins – 48%
  • Dizygotic twins – 12%

questions.text: Obsession is a disorder of which part of thinking
questions.solution:
Obsession is a disorder of thought content as per Fish's classification of thought disorders.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder is defined as the presence of obsessions and/or compulsions.

  • Obsessions are recurrent and persistent ideas, thoughts, urges, or images that are experienced as intrusive and unwanted and cause anxiety or distress to the patients.
  • Compulsions are the repetitive and intentional behaviours or acts performed in response to obsessions or according to certain rules that must be applied rigidly (e.g., repetitive hand washing, ritualistic checking).

 

Controversial : The classification of OCD as a certain form of thought is debatable based on the resource. Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th Edition) lists it under disorders of content of thought, whilst Fish's Clinical Psychopathology (4th Edition) mentions it under disorders of possession of thought. Hence, the answer depends on the book referred by the examiner while framing the question.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

questions.text: All of the following are seen in PTSD, except:
questions.solution:
Hallucination is not seen in Post traumatic stress disorder.

Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is an anxiety disorder that occurs after and as a result of a major, disturbing, out of the ordinary event in a person’s life, such as war or rape. 

The prominent symptoms of this disorder include

  • Nightmares
  • Flashbacks
  • Withdrawal i.e. avoidance and emotional numbing
  • Hypervigilance/hyperarousal

questions.text: All of the following are features of Atypical Depression, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Astasia-abasia is a feature of conversion disorder. It refers to inability to stand or walk in a normal manner, even though normal leg movements can be performed in a sitting or lying down position.

Symptoms of depression with atypical features include the following:

A. Mood reactivity (i.e., mood brightens in response to positive events)

B. Two or more of the following features, present for most of the time, for at least two weeks:

  1. Increased appetite
  2. Increased sleep
  3. Leaden paralysis (i.e., heavy, leaden feelings in arms or legs)
  4. Interpersonal rejection sensitivity (not limited to episodes of mood disturbance) resulting in significant social or occupational impairment

C. Criteria are not met for melancholic or catatonic features of depression.

questions.text: True about cluster headache is all except:
questions.solution:
Cluster headache is stabbing or boring type of headache. Pulsatile headache is a feature of migraine.

Cluster headache:

  • More common in males
  • Cluster refers to a “clustering in time,” i.e. frequent intense attacks (often several per day) over a 1- to 2-month period, separated by headache-free intervals for as long as 1 or 2 years.
  • Unilateral
  • Periorbital/retro-orbital/tempora
  • Stabbing or boring kind of pain
  • Accompanied by autonomic changes such as lacrimation, rhinorrhea, erythema of the eye, and agitation.
  • Patients with cluster headache do not retire to dark rooms and lie down to avoid the stimulation, but may in fact do quite the opposite, appearing almost manic in their agitation. The pain can be so intense that the sufferer may appear to be psychotic because of the screaming and thrashing that may be associated with the pain.
  • Prior smoking and alcohol use have been associated with cluster headache, with alcohol often triggering the onset of the headache.

Treatment:

  • 100%O2 for acute cases
  • Prophylaxis – Lithium, Verapamil, methysergide, topiramate.

questions.text: All are features of Delirium except
questions.solution:
Vomiting can lead to metabolic disturbances and thus act as precipitating factor for delirium but not a feature of delirium.

Option a: Disorientation especially for time is a prominent feature of delirium.

Option b: The frequent finding of impaired memory usually represents an inability to register recent information because of inattentiveness, but retrieval of older information can also be disturbed.

Higher integrative functions are similarly affected; the result is a reduced ability to plan, solve problems, or guide actions.

These disturbances in attention often increase toward evening, a characteristic known as sundowning, which may result from fatigue and reduced sensory input.

Option c: Delirium is classified based on psychomotor activity into hyperactive type (increased psychomotor activity) and hypoactive type (decreased psychomotor activity).

questions.text: Novelty seeking is associated with all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Novelty seeking (NS) is a temperament trait in the Cloninger’s model of personality and refers to the tendency to be intensely exhilarated or excited in response to novel stimuli.

Individuals high in novelty seeking are quick-tempered, curious, easily bored, impulsive, extravagant, and disorderly.

High novelty seeking is related to addiction, ADHD and impulsivity.

Persons low in novelty seeking are slow tempered, uninquiring, stoical, reflective, frugal, reserved, tolerant of monotony, and orderly.

Individuals with schizoid personality have low novelty seeking behavior.

Cluster B personality disorder like borderline, histrionic, narcissistic and antisocial have high novelty seeking behavior.

questions.text: A patient on treatment for a psychiatric disorder takes one of his medicines in excess and develops tachycardia, postural hypotension, decreased sweating and dry mouth. Which of the following drug was likely taken by this patient?
questions.solution:
The above symptoms are suggestive of amitriptyline overdosage.

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant. Its side effects are

  • Weight gain and sedation - H1 antagonism
  • Anticholinergic effects like blurred vision, dry mouth, tachycardia, constipation, difficulty urinating - Antagonism of Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors
  • Orthostatic hypotension - Antagonism of α1 adrenergic receptors
  • Cardiac conduction delay – acts like Class 1A antiarrhythmic agents(quinidine- like effects)

Amitriptyline causes tachycardia and cardiac conduction delay (and not bradycardia as explained previously)

questions.text: Couvade syndrome refers to

choices.text: Pregnant female believes that she is not pregnant

questions.solution:
• Couvade syndrome is the common but poorly understood phenomenon whereby the expectant father experiences somatic symptoms during the pregnancy for which there is no recognized physiological basis.
  • Symptoms commonly include indigestion, increased or decreased appetite, weight gain, diarrhea or constipation, headache, and toothache.
  • Onset is usually during the third gestational month with a secondary rise in the late third trimester.
  • Symptoms generally resolve with childbirth.
  • Couvade has been seen as an expression of somatized anxiety, pseudo-sibling rivalry, identification with the fetus, ambivalence about fatherhood, a statement of paternity, or parturition envy.
